articles.headline: With a No-Fail Mission, the Secret Service Strains to Make Do
articles.snippet: The agency charged with protecting presidents and foreign leaders has its largest ever budget, but employees say it is still unable to recruit and retain enough people to carry the load.
articles.abstract: The agency charged with protecting presidents and foreign leaders has its largest ever budget, but employees say it is still unable to recruit and retain enough people to carry the load.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the years, whenever the United States Secret Service’s lack of resources has been an issue, agents invoke a tongue-in-cheek motto: We do more with less.

articles.headline: Rail Sabotage Blights an Olympic Moment for France
articles.snippet: The arson attacks were carefully planned to cause maximum disruption on a train network so vast it is virtually impossible to fully secure.
articles.abstract: The arson attacks were carefully planned to cause maximum disruption on a train network so vast it is virtually impossible to fully secure.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before dawn on the day of the opening ceremony of the Paris Olympics, arsonists on Friday sabotaged three critical high-speed rail lines, stranding thousands of travelers, heightening security fears and blighting what President Emmanuel Macron hoped to be a moment of national glory.
articles.byline: By Catherine Porter and Aurelien Breeden

articles.headline: How the U.S. Captured One of Mexico’s Biggest Drug Lords
articles.snippet: The improbable arrest of Ismael Zambada García, who for decades had evaded the authorities, at a small airport outside El Paso appears to be a tale of subterfuge and betrayal.
articles.abstract: The improbable arrest of Ismael Zambada García, who for decades had evaded the authorities, at a small airport outside El Paso appears to be a tale of subterfuge and betrayal.
articles.lead_paragraph: It sounded like a story ripped from a narco thriller: One of the biggest drug lords in Mexico was lured onto an airplane, flown across the border and presented to American federal agents by the son of his former partner in crime.
articles.byline: By Alan Feuer, Natalie Kitroeff and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega

articles.headline: A Digital Coin Based on Baby Trump? Yup.
articles.snippet: One of the wildest, most scam-ridden corners of the cryptocurrency industry — memecoins, which are rooted in internet memes — has roared back.
articles.abstract: One of the wildest, most scam-ridden corners of the cryptocurrency industry — memecoins, which are rooted in internet memes — has roared back.
articles.lead_paragraph: Josh Bailey, a 26-year-old day trader in Austin, Texas, was scrolling through a cryptocurrency group chat last month when he encountered an investment opportunity: a digital currency created in honor of a dog named Billy.

articles.headline: Away From the War in Gaza, Another Palestinian Economy Is Wrecked
articles.snippet: With the closure of checkpoints, Israeli Arabs cannot come to Jenin and Tulkarm to shop, and West Bank Palestinians cannot leave to work in Israel, cutting incomes and building militancy.
articles.abstract: With the closure of checkpoints, Israeli Arabs cannot come to Jenin and Tulkarm to shop, and West Bank Palestinians cannot leave to work in Israel, cutting incomes and building militancy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than three years ago, Wassif Frahat spent $3 million to open a lavish, two-story restaurant, the Ali Baba. With an impressive, pillared entryway, polished stone floors, glittering chandeliers and colorful frescoes on the high ceilings, the restaurant was his commitment to a better future.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Sergey Ponomarev

articles.headline: JD Vance, an Unlikely Friendship and Why It Ended
articles.snippet: His political views differed from a transgender classmate’s, but they forged a bond that lasted a decade — until Mr. Vance seemed to pivot, politically and personally.
articles.abstract: His political views differed from a transgender classmate’s, but they forged a bond that lasted a decade — until Mr. Vance seemed to pivot, politically and personally.
articles.lead_paragraph: When his book, “Hillbilly Elegy,” was published in 2016, JD Vance sent an email apologizing to a close friend from his Yale Law School days. The friend identified as transgender, but Mr. Vance referred to them in the book as a lesbian.

articles.headline: JD Vance Stumbles in His Debut, as Democrats Go on Offense
articles.snippet: In the 12 days since Ohio’s junior senator was tapped as the future of Donald J. Trump’s movement, old comments and a chorus of derision have blunted any sense of invulnerability.
articles.abstract: In the 12 days since Ohio’s junior senator was tapped as the future of Donald J. Trump’s movement, old comments and a chorus of derision have blunted any sense of invulnerability.
articles.lead_paragraph: The choice of Senator JD Vance as former President Donald J. Trump’s running mate reflected the confidence of a campaign so sure of victory in November that it could look beyond a second Trump term to the legacy of his movement.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Shane Goldmacher

articles.headline: Fears of Escalation After Rocket From Lebanon Hits Soccer Field
articles.snippet: Diplomats were scrambling to prevent a surge in fighting, officials said, after Israel retaliated for the rocket fire that killed at least 12 children and teenagers in an Israeli-controlled town.
articles.abstract: Diplomats were scrambling to prevent a surge in fighting, officials said, after Israel retaliated for the rocket fire that killed at least 12 children and teenagers in an Israeli-controlled town.
articles.lead_paragraph: Western diplomats were scrambling on Sunday to prevent a surge of fighting along the Israel-Lebanon border, officials said, after a rocket from Lebanon on Saturday killed at least 12 children and teenagers in an Israeli-controlled town. The rocket prompted Israel to retaliate early Sunday with strikes across Lebanon.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley, Euan Ward and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: Simone Biles Is Done Being Judged
articles.snippet: Three years after she dropped out of the Tokyo Games with a mental block, she is back at the Olympics with a defiant attitude — and a sense of where she is in the air.
articles.abstract: Three years after she dropped out of the Tokyo Games with a mental block, she is back at the Olympics with a defiant attitude — and a sense of where she is in the air.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow live updates of the women’s gymnastics qualifying at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

articles.headline: Hollywood’s Message to Red States: Our Movies Are for You
articles.snippet: After a period of openly using movies to display progressive values, studios seem to be heeding a message from many ticket buyers: Just entertain us.
articles.abstract: After a period of openly using movies to display progressive values, studios seem to be heeding a message from many ticket buyers: Just entertain us.
articles.lead_paragraph: For nearly two decades, Hollywood has seemingly missed no opportunity to sound the alarm about climate change.

articles.headline: A Pedigreed Rail Magnate Is Pouring Millions Into Electing Donald Trump
articles.snippet: Timothy Mellon, a reclusive heir to a storied fortune, is spending tens of millions to elect Donald J. Trump. Precisely what he wants in return is one of many curiosities surrounding him.
articles.abstract: Timothy Mellon, a reclusive heir to a storied fortune, is spending tens of millions to elect Donald J. Trump. Precisely what he wants in return is one of many curiosities surrounding him.
articles.lead_paragraph: Timothy Mellon, a wealthy banking heir and railroad magnate, has reached the stratosphere of American political influence as the top supporter of Donald J. Trump, doling out millions to try to elect the former president and his allies.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Berzon and Mike McIntire

articles.headline: Racked by Pain and Enraptured by a Right-Wing Miracle Cure
articles.snippet: With Patriot Party News, Michael Chesebro found a sense of community, and a place where conspiracy theories could become real in the form of the “medbed.”
articles.abstract: With Patriot Party News, Michael Chesebro found a sense of community, and a place where conspiracy theories could become real in the form of the “medbed.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael Chesebro awoke to the same reality as he did each morning, with pain radiating up his spine and into his shoulders before he opened his eyes. He remained still for a moment, summoning the courage to reach from his bed to his night stand. He rolled onto his back, which was fused together with metal after almost 20 years as a paratrooper in the military. He extended his arm, which he had broken several times while wrangling bulls and horses on his ranch outside Cheyenne, Wyo. Finally, his hand found his cellphone, and he logged on to the online universe where he spent most of his days.

articles.headline: Business Is Buzzing Again for the Meme Makers of the Left
articles.snippet: After a few sluggish years under President Biden, liberal social media creators are seeing their messages resonate as Kamala Harris campaigns for the White House.
articles.abstract: After a few sluggish years under President Biden, liberal social media creators are seeing their messages resonate as Kamala Harris campaigns for the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Sunday, after President Biden announced he was stepping down from his presidential campaign and endorsing Kamala Harris as his replacement, Democratic meme makers rejoiced.

articles.headline: The Quiet Bond Kamala Harris Forged With Three V.P. Contenders
articles.snippet: The vice president is considering several men who also served as state attorneys general. Those relationships could inform her crucial decision in the days ahead.
articles.abstract: The vice president is considering several men who also served as state attorneys general. Those relationships could inform her crucial decision in the days ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: When President Biden introduced Kamala Harris as his running mate four years ago, he shared their origin story: He had first learned of her, he said, through his son Beau, who served with her as a state attorney general.

articles.headline: As F-16s Arrive, Ukraine Still Faces Steep Challenges in the Skies
articles.snippet: Ukraine wants to deploy its first F-16 jets this summer, hoping to counter Russia’s dominance in the air. But stepped-up Russian bombing attacks on air bases complicate the effort.
articles.abstract: Ukraine wants to deploy its first F-16 jets this summer, hoping to counter Russia’s dominance in the air. But stepped-up Russian bombing attacks on air bases complicate the effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: The surveillance drone appeared high above the Ukrainian air base without warning in early July. Minutes after it relayed targeting data back to a Russian base, a barrage of ballistic missiles struck the airfield, Ukrainian officials said, recounting the episode.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Gunman at Trump Rally Was Often a Step Ahead of the Secret Service
articles.snippet: Text messages, obtained exclusively by The Times, indicate that some law enforcement officers were aware of Thomas Crooks earlier than previously known. And he was aware of them.
articles.abstract: Text messages, obtained exclusively by The Times, indicate that some law enforcement officers were aware of Thomas Crooks earlier than previously known. And he was aware of them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly 100 minutes before former President Donald J. Trump took the stage in Butler, Pa., a local countersniper who was part of the broader security detail let his colleagues know his shift was ending.
articles.byline: By Haley Willis, Aric Toler, David A. Fahrenthold and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Japan Wanted Higher Inflation. It’s Here, and It Hurts.
articles.snippet: Japan’s economy is faltering after a rise in prices led consumers to cut back on spending.
articles.abstract: Japan’s economy is faltering after a rise in prices led consumers to cut back on spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the rest of the world fought to keep inflation in check, one country welcomed it with open arms.

articles.headline: Germans Combat Climate Change From Their Balconies
articles.snippet: Plug-and-play solar panels are popping up in yards and on balcony railings across Germany, driven by bargain prices and looser regulations.
articles.abstract: Plug-and-play solar panels are popping up in yards and on balcony railings across Germany, driven by bargain prices and looser regulations.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a Berlin trade fair for sustainability, a new gadget caught Waltraud Berg’s eye — a solar panel small enough to be easily installed on the side of a balcony and then plugged into a wall socket to feed energy produced by the sun directly into her home.

articles.headline: Warning of ‘Extreme’ Agenda, Biden Calls for Supreme Court Overhaul
articles.snippet: In a speech in Austin, Texas, the president outlined a proposal that included term limits and an enforceable ethics code for the justices but that faces long odds in a divided Congress.
articles.abstract: In a speech in Austin, Texas, the president outlined a proposal that included term limits and an enforceable ethics code for the justices but that faces long odds in a divided Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden, warning that the country’s courts were being weaponized as part of an “extreme and unchecked” conservative agenda, said on Monday that he would push for legislation that would bring major changes to the Supreme Court, including term limits and an enforceable code of ethics on the justices.

articles.headline: It’s Silicon Valley vs. Silicon Valley as Political Fights Escalate
articles.snippet: Elon Musk, Reid Hoffman and other tech billionaires, many of whom are part of the “PayPal Mafia,” are openly brawling with one another over politics as tensions rise.
articles.abstract: Elon Musk, Reid Hoffman and other tech billionaires, many of whom are part of the “PayPal Mafia,” are openly brawling with one another over politics as tensions rise.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than an hour after a gunman in Butler, Pa., tried to assassinate Donald J. Trump this month, David Sacks, a venture capitalist based in San Francisco, directed his anger about the incident toward a former colleague.
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac, Erin Griffith and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: How One Man Lost $740,000 to Scammers Targeting His Retirement Savings
articles.snippet: Criminals on the internet are increasingly going after Americans over the age of 60 because they are viewed as having the largest piles of savings.
articles.abstract: Criminals on the internet are increasingly going after Americans over the age of 60 because they are viewed as having the largest piles of savings.
articles.lead_paragraph: For nearly three months, Barry Heitin, a 76-year-old retired lawyer, thought he was part of a government investigation that felt like something out of the movies. He was actually assisting criminals in stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars — of his own money.
